original_data.question:
A 57-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency department because of several episodes of hematemesis in the past 24 hours. His vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse of 95/min, and blood pressure of 85/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, he appears confused and unable to give a complete history. He is noted to have jaundice, palpable firm liver, mild splenomegaly, and shifting dullness consistent with the presence of ascites. Liver function tests are as follows:
Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  97 U/L
Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 40 U/L
Serum albumin 2.5 g/dL
Total bilirubin 3 mg/dL
Prothrombin time 20 seconds
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?

model_response:
This patient's presentation is most consistent with decompensated cirrhosis. The elevated prothrombin time indicates that the liver is unable to synthesize clotting factors. The elevated bilirubin level indicates that the liver is unable to conjugate bilirubin. The elevated AST and ALT levels indicate that the liver is unable to metabolize these enzymes, which are released from damaged hepatocytes. The elevated alkaline phosphatase level indicates that there is some biliary tract obstruction. The elevated albumin level indicates that the liver is still synthesizing proteins. The presence of ascites indicates that the liver is unable to metabolize fluids. The cause of this patient's cirrhosis is most likely hepatic venous outflow obstruction secondary to alcoholic liver disease. The homeless population is at high risk for alcoholism. The patient's hematemesis is secondary to esophageal varices, which are a complication of portal hypertension. The patient's mental obtundation is secondary to hepatic encephalopathy, which is caused by the liver's inability to metabolize ammonia.

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Persons without adequate housing or without permanent residence. The concept excludes nomadic peoples.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
Vomiting of blood that is either fresh bright red, or older "coffee-ground" in character. It generally indicates bleeding of the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Record and study of past events.
A clinical manifestation of HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA, characterized by the yellowish staining of the SKIN; MUCOUS MEMBRANE; and SCLERA. Clinical jaundice usually is a sign of LIVER dysfunction.
Having a structure or consistency that strongly resists stress or pressure.
A large lobed glandular organ in the abdomen of vertebrates that is responsible for detoxification, metabolism, synthesis and storage of various substances.
Marked by a reasonable or logical relation of parts and holding together as a harmonious or credible whole.
Accumulation or retention of free fluid within the peritoneal cavity.
Blood tests that are used to evaluate how well a patient's liver is working and also to help diagnose liver conditions.
Enzymes of the transferase class that catalyze the conversion of L-aspartate and 2-ketoglutarate to oxaloacetate and L-glutamate. EC 2.6.1.1.
Enzymes of the transferase class that catalyze the conversion of L-aspartate and 2-ketoglutarate to oxaloacetate and L-glutamate. EC 2.6.1.1.
An enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of L-alanine and 2-oxoglutarate to pyruvate and L-glutamate. (From Enzyme Nomenclature, 1992) EC 2.6.1.2.
A bile pigment that is a degradation product of HEME.

Clotting time of PLASMA recalcified in the presence of excess TISSUE THROMBOPLASTIN. Factors measured are FIBRINOGEN; PROTHROMBIN; FACTOR V; FACTOR VII; and FACTOR X. It is used for monitoring anticoagulant therapy with COUMARINS.
